subtitle: The inaugural issue of the New Thinking Allowed
magazine was just released on March 1st.
You can download a free PDF copy from the New Thinking Allowed Foundation website.
That's newthinkingallowed.org.
You can even order a printed copy from nta-magazine.magcloud.com.
Thinking Allowed – conversations on the
leading edge of knowledge and discovery with
psychologist Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello and welcome.
I'm Jeffrey Mishlove.
Today we will be exploring animal communication.
With me is Linda Tellington-Jones, a world-class expert in that field.
She is the founder of the Tellington TTouch Method.
Today, over 2,500 people have been trained
in the use of this method on every continent
except Antarctica.
She is the author of more than 20 books, including the Tellington TTouch.
Welcome.
Thank you.
It's my pleasure.
I'm very excited to be here with you.
It's a pleasure to be with you once again.
And you, as we discussed in a previous interview
on opening to intuition, you've been working
with animals all of your life.
It seems to me that you probably have a natural
gift for it because, well, not only were you
exposed to animals intimately since childhood,
but maybe there are other factors as well.
One of the interesting things that you wrote
about in your book is how from time to time
you have an experience in which it appears it's as if the animal is communicating to
you like in language, that you can have a
detailed, involved conversation with an animal.
Well, I would say maybe I have to think about that
because my feeling is that animal communication
is really important in this connection with our animals.
And I was first exposed to it, actually, Jeffrey,
by my grandfather, Will Kaywood, whom I did
not know until he was 80 years old.
That's another whole story.
He came to the ranch where my first husband and I had 90 thoroughbred racehorses and 30
Arabian horses, and he had been a racing trainer
all those years, and he came to visit us.
And he had been a young jockey, a very successful young jockey.
When he was 21, his agent hired him out to
an Austrian racehorse owner, and he actually
– I have his passport and visa and letter – he was taken to Russia to ride these horses
of this trainer.
And he liked it a lot, and so he stayed on and became a trainer at the Hippodrome in
Moscow where I actually had the amazing synchronicity
and pleasure to sit in the same place where
he would have watched the races in Moscow when I was there as a citizen diplomat.
And that was 1984 on my first trip there.
I had no idea they had horse racing in Moscow.
Oh, it's huge.
It's huge, St. Petersburg and Moscow and many other tracks.
But my grandfather in 1905 won the prestigious
leading trainer award from Tsar Nicholas II,
and he had a jeweled cane as a reward, and he had 87 winners in that year.
Now what's important in our discussion about
that is that he said that his success was
due to two factors.
Number one, every horse in his stable was rubbed with these short little strokes over
the whole body by the grooms.
And the grooms still at the racetracks are Russian gypsies.
And he said also that he never entered a horse
in a race unless it told him they were feeling
fit enough to really run well.
Now that was the first I actually, that's 1960, that he came to us.
That's the first I'd even thought about animal communication.
And since then I've had, of course, I use it all the time.
It's really important.
Do you say 1960?
Uh-huh.
Yeah.
Okay.
And by then you had already been actively involved, obviously, in the world of horse
racing.
We bred horses to race, and we bred yearlings to sell in those for years.
That was just before we left that world and
started the Pacific Coast Equestrian Research
Farm.
So anyway, what interests me today is the
connection we can have with animals at a heart
connection and this intuitive connection.
And I don't actually feel like I talk to animals,
wait a minute, erase that Linda, not true.
I actually use the words to talk to animals if I have an intent.
For instance, can you please take two steps forward?
When I'm working with an animal on the ground,
I really pay attention to that because if
I speak the words, and I always ask them,
thanks to Dr. Imoto's wonderful work, Messages
from Water, the concept that if we ask or
we command, it's a totally different result.
If I, for instance, say to a horse or a dog,
or do it, there is no crystalline form in
Dr. Imoto's work.
If I say, let's do it, can we do that together
as an invitation, and I say please and thank
you often, something else happens at the level of communication.
It's really different.
Well, you've said something crucial already
because what you're doing is you're throwing
out the, I will call it, the obedience paradigm.
Gone.
Yes.
So it's an invitation for us to come from the heart, working together.
Many people, I mean, we talk about obedience
training with dogs, it seems that that's sort
of the dominant model.
It's totally the same with horses.
You're going to, what's the word, I can't even think of the word.
Show them who's boss.
Show them who's boss, dominate that horse.
And you know what, in this day and age, there's
a whole other way of being with our dogs.
This thing of commanding and operant
conditioning, there's a whole other way of being.
And I am, since 1997, I have been working
with the concept of HeartMath Institute, and
they have done some really beautiful studies.
Roland McCready's son, Josh, actually did something working with his dog and being in
heart coherence, as measured by HeartMath's
little M-Wave, and showing that when we invite,
when we are in this place of heart coherence,
rather than this command dominant position,
that dogs and the horses want to be with us.
It's a really beautiful study that one of their people also did with horses, showing
that when I sit there and I'm in a place of heart coherence, that is thinking pleasant
thoughts, that horses who were free and loose in a paddock would come up to them.
And when you get in that commanding, dominating way, they would stay away.
They can feel it.
I'm also like a, I am a great student and
proponent of this concept of the mirror neurons,
because how we are feeling affects that animal, and they know it.
So for me to come from a place of invitation
when I'm connecting or communicating with
an animal has a totally different effect, not just on the animal, Jeffrey, but on me
also.
Because if your listeners don't know HeartMath
Institute, get on Google and get acquainted,
because their work is, I think, one of the most important on the planet.
If you want to be with an animal in a way that they want to be with you, come from a
place of invitation, of honoring, of respecting, of seeing their soul.
That's why I believe animals respond to me in such a way that they do.
When we acknowledge that individuality and
the gifts that coming from a heart place with
them makes, the life is very different, and the animal wants to connect with us.
That's what I'm about, is animal interspecies connections.
I think you've worked with not just domesticated
animals, but with, I guess, what are commonly
known as exotic animals as well, and some of them are not friendly.
Well, I want to tell you a couple of what I call profound interspecies connections.
One of them was a six-month-old bear that was
separated from his mother during the Mount
St. Helens eruption.
Oh, yes.
There were a lot of animals, a lot of bears that were separated, and this one bear had
been picked up, and he had the shakes.
I mean, he had neurological damage to him.
When he'd stand up, he'd shake all over.
Somebody in their meeting had heard about
my animal ambassador program, because I have
a non-profit organization called Animal Ambassadors
that actually started in Russia when I was
there.
Anyway, they called me, and I happened to be that day in my office in Santa Fe.
I think it was about 1986, maybe, and so I
happened to pick up the phone, and they wanted
to know, would we be interested in seeing if we could rehab this bear?
So we said, yes, of course, and we paid to fly
him down to Texas A&M University vet school,
and they checked him out and then turned him over
to us, and we had one of our animal ambassador
members at that time had a big kennel for a Great Dane, but the Great Dane had passed
on and she had this big dog house in an enclosed area.
So we brought him there on a hot Texas day, and actually an organization called Kids TV
Express wanted to film us and this first interaction with this bear.
And what I have to tell you about young bears, they're really friendly.
They're not unfriendly.
They're quite amazing.
Also polar bears.
When they're young.
When they're young, yes, the babies, because
they're not afraid, so they have no reason
to be aggressive.
I want to come back to that subject, actually.
And so I just, he was in his house, and just
looking at all of us, kids were on the outside
of the enclosure, and one of them was in with the camera.
And so I just started, not right directly in
front of him, but a little bit to the side.
I just came in and I took a little piece of
rubber hose and I just started doing tea touches
on his paws at first, and he was just looking
at me, totally unafraid, did a few little
circles.
That's all, because he's little, moving his skin gently in one and a quarter circles.
It makes a cell to cell connection.
And I'm asked often, well, okay, Linda, how come it is that you can work with so many
different species?
How come you know so much?
I don't know so much, Jeffrey.
I ask the keeper, I ask the vet, I ask the people who know these animals, what's your
experience with them?
And then I simply allow the animal to see me.
And I'm very careful.
I am never stupid, because it's really important
that I also keep the animal in a place of
non-fear.
Okay.
So that's why you use the hose.
A little extension, not my actual hands.
It was just a little short piece.
So the animal isn't being threatened by your proximity.
That's right.
That's right.
And I'm not facing him.
I'm using my own language, like little to the side, so he can see me.
Because if I face onward, that's like he can't escape, right?
So I always leave an escape route.
That's basic, good manners, and good sense.
Well, I mean, like in a normal human communication,
eye-to-eye contact is important, but I guess
animals might be threatened by that.
Depending on the culture.
Every animal has a different culture.
Well, not just the animals, but also our culture
around the world, if it depends, that eye-to-eye
thing, right?
I mean, you don't do that in every culture.
That's right.
So anyway, so I just did a couple of minutes,
and I sat back and let him look around and
think, because I wanted him to see us and to know we're not threatening.
Okay.
So then I go back after three or four minutes,
and then I just took his paw, put my hand
out, and he put his paw in my hand, and that was my intent.
Can you please, that's my, can you put your paw in my hand, okay?
So he put his paw, and I do a little tiny what we call raccoon touches, because every
different way we have of using our name is named after an animal I've worked with.
So you know how raccoons have these little movements.
So I did these little touches around his nails,
and I just said to him, now, be very aware
of your claws, be very calm, you know, with your paws.
So and then I sat back again, and then I, there's pictures of me with my hands, like
under his little chin, he said, just working
around the mouth, because working around the
mouth actually affects the limbic system.
It's the closest connection to the limbic system that affects our emotions.
So I'm doing this little chin thing, and he's
just looking at me, like not more than two
minutes max.
Sit back again, and then I sat back a little
farther, and in those days, I didn't have
glasses on, so I take my glasses off, I mean,
no, I didn't, I didn't have glasses on, sorry,
and I'm kneeling down, and he slowly comes out, and I was about six feet to the side
of the entrance, he came out this, here's his little snout coming toward me, and just
this slowly, he came, he picked up my eyelashes,
gently lifted this eyelid out, put it back
this slowly, just went like this with his
little lips and snout, and went to the other
side, lifted them out, put it back, slowly
sat down, looked me straight in the eye, and
then turned and walked over and sat in a tub
of water, because it was really hot in Austin
that day, and it was one, that's what I call
a profound interspecies connection, and people
say to me, Linda, weren't you terrified, his
intent, Jeffrey, was so clear that he meant
no harm, and it was such a careful approach that I could, I mean, it was like, one of
the most beautiful experiences of my life,
and that was his way of saying, we can trust
each other, can't we?
Well, your work is largely about trust.
It is.
It's about trust and honoring the individuality
of that being, but also it's this cell-to-cell
connection, because in the mitochondria, in
the nucleus of the cell, we're all one, we're
all one.
In the nucleus of the cell.
In the center of the cell, the divine spark is in every cell in the body of everything
on the planet.
Like the DNA.
It's the divine spark.
Okay.
So, I mean, it might be at the quantum level.
Yes, yes, at the quantum level.
And it's interesting, I've been searching for these words that makes this connection.
For me, it's the cell-to-cell connection.
It's also the soul-to-soul connection, which is
really interesting, because the way I developed
this tea touch that makes this phenomenal
interspecies connection was, you know, first
of all, my grandfather came to me with this
form of Russian gypsy massage, and my husband
and I wrote the first book that we can find on
massage and physical therapy for the athletic
horse.
He self-published it, and then it was in another, it was a published book later.
So for 15 years, we did this form of massage for my grandfather.
And it was very effective in helping our
horses recover after hard physical endeavor.
I did a lot of 100-mile endurance riding and
horse shows and steeplechasing and all that
stuff in my career.
Anyway, it never affected the personality of the animal, however.
And I, in those, it was 1960 when I first heard
about this concept of animal communication.
And in those days, Beatrice Lidecker was the
first person I'd ever heard of who was very
famous for animal communication.
And she was pretty amazing, because we had, one of my clients had a horse who'd had a
fall on a jump and was lame, and they couldn't
figure out the lameness, that no vet could
figure out what was wrong.
And so I said, well, let me call Beatrice Lidecker on the phone.
So I called her, and she said, well, put the
horse to the phone, the phone to the horse.
I have no idea how we did it, and they say, you don't have to do that anymore, because
you can do it with a picture or parapsychology, right?
Well, telepathy.
Telepathy.
So anyway, she said, well, you know what, that horse had a jump pole hit the horse in
the shoulder.
If you take it to the vet at Vets at Davis, tell them to go in nine inches and told us
exactly where to go, they will find a pocket
of pus that is making that horse lame.
And they did.
Oh my.
That was pretty interesting.
That would have been an eye-opener.
And then another situation, I can't remember why I called her on this one.
I mean, we're talking, like, many, many years ago, right?
What was that?
Oh, I know.
It was somebody who had bought a bull, a very
expensive breeding bull, and he wasn't doing
his job.
He wasn't potent enough.
He wasn't interested.
It was a very strange deal.
So we said, well, wait a minute, of course,
they'd done all the vet things to check this
bull.
Nothing.
Okay.
So I called her, and she said, you know what,
what I see is that before they sold this bull,
he was out in an area where he could see
other animals, and it was really interesting.
And there was a red dog that he connected to.
And now he's kept in a dark place, and he can't see anything, and he's depressed.
And that was the truth.
And they changed the place, and it made a difference.
So that was pretty interesting, you know, after my grandfather's story.
So over the years, if I have an issue with an animal, I ask somebody else if it's an
animal close to me.
If somebody comes to me wanting to connect
how does the animal feel, I use kinesiology.
And I teach people to use their own body to
get a yes and a no, and they can make a direct
connection with the universe to ask about the animal, or they can ask the animal how
they're feeling.
But you have to be really careful about this,
because, you know, you have to be very respectful
of this.
So I just love this concept of how we can connect with our animals.
And you referred earlier to cell-to-cell communication when you do the touch.
It's as if your cells at a cellular level are communicating with the animal.
Yes.
And how I got to that concept, it was in 1976 in February.
I was in the four-year professional Feldenkrais
training at the Humanistic Psychology Institute
with Dr. Moshe Feldenkrais, and he had given
us a number of books that we were to read
and study.
And one of the books was called Man on His Nature by Sir Charles Sherrington.
And now, actually, on Amazon, you can actually get them for a reasonable price.
A few years ago, it was like $136 for a copy.
I still have my original.
So I'm sitting in Marvenpick Restaurant in Stuttgart, Germany.
I remember exactly where I was sitting, and
I read a statement that said that every cell
in the body knows its function within the body and its function within the universe.
Now, I normally don't say that second part, because it's hard enough to get the first
part, right?
Yeah.
But wait, wait a minute.
It was after the first year of my Feldenkrais
training with Moshe Feldenkrais, and we had
watched him do just make miraculous changes
in a person that summer who had had a stroke,
but we didn't yet know how to do this.
And so when I read this statement by Sherrington,
every cell in the body knows its function
within the body, I thought, whoa, wait a minute,
when I don't know how to do this amazing Feldenkrais
work yet, all I have to do is say, cells,
just talk to this body and remind their cells
for their potential for ideal function.
And that's how I started seeing the body as a collection of cells.
And that's how I started connecting with animals in another way.
And this question of trust that comes up, you
see, we talked earlier about this dominance
concept that we have to dominate the animal.
Until 1981, if an animal, if a dog growled or bit or a horse kicked or bit, punish it
instantly.
Right?
Yep.
Of course, you have to dominate them.
Show them who's boss, as you said.
But I read one statement in this year-long
course in miracles that changed my life with
animals.
And the sentence was, aggression comes from a place of fear and is a cry for help.
And when I read that, I thought of all over
the years, I mean, I was a really kind person
compared to most with horses, but that was my business.
You bite me, I'm going to whack you, kick, I'm going to really whack you.
And I thought, wait a minute, you know what, there's another way.
If that is from fear, what am I doing, just punishing that animal for that?
How can I, wait a minute, step back and be
with that horse or dog or even cat, whatever
animal in a way that I don't threaten them and they won't be fearful?
And in that moment, I changed my approach completely.
And I think this is so important, Jeffrey, in this day and age, because when we meet
aggression with aggression, whether it's with
an animal or an adult or a child, we're not
acknowledging what's the core of it.
And it doesn't mean, as my brilliant sister
Robin Hood, who also teaches Telling to Teach
Around the World, as she says, understanding
behavior does not excuse it, how can we find
a way to support that animal in coming from a place of trust rather than fear?
And that's where this communication and this connection comes in.
Now, I have a sense that deep within the
brain, the fear instinct is in every person.
Totally.
And somewhere deep within us, we're like a
little sparrow or something, like constantly
on the alert for something that's going to jump out of the bushes at us.
No question.
And that is important that we have that, actually.
But when it's totally triggerable because
we're in such a state of high anxiety because
of listening to the news or reading all this
stuff that's going on around the world, we're
contributing to the problem and we're sure injuring ourselves.
And this is, for me, what you say about the fear being in every cell, I've done a lot
of past life regressions, really important ones, actually, with Chris Griskam at her
institute in Galaseo.
And I did a session one day and I saw within
my own body that in every cell in our body,
we are carrying every emotion, every fear, hatred, jealousy, all the negative emotions
that any person has ever had on this planet.
It's part of our makeup.
It's part of why we're here on the planet
is to make a decision that when we recognize
that we can let go of fear, and it may not
be our own, that we make a difference on the
planet.
One of my favorite books over all these years
has been Jerry Jampolsky's beautiful, classic
little book, Love is Letting Go of Fear.
So after that session with Chris Griskam, we went for a walk in the Bosque, I was in
New Mexico, and I said, okay, Chris, so as we recognize and learn how to release that
fear by step by step, learning how we dare to trust, what's left?
And of course, the answer is love.
We leave space for love.
And that's where with the animals, we have to learn to give them boundaries.
Because if we don't create our own boundaries
or create boundaries that are respectful,
that are clear, that are kind, they don't know how to function in our world.
And so, I mean, one of the common things so many...
I work a lot in animal shelters, all of our people do, around the world.
And one of the common things that dogs get sent back to in shelters are pulling on the
leash because the person can't handle them,
and barking, you know, or jumping up or being
in a way that is not comfortable for the person.
And that's where we've developed these different
ways of working so that the owner can bring
that animal in a kind, respectful way of being able to have these boundaries.
For me, it's about communicating at another level.
Well, it's interesting you keep referring to
every cell in the body, because as I think
about the evolution of life, we all started
out as single-celled creatures, even humans.
That's how we begin our life.
So there's a sense in which we are a composite
of, I don't know, hundreds of billions of
little animals inside of us.
Cells, yes.
And I love this second co-authored book by Bruce Lipton.
It's a funny title, but it'll come to me in a moment.
Of course, Biology of Belief is his first one, and what is it, The Honeymoon Effect
is the second, is the third one.
But in the middle, he wrote a wonderful book called, What the Heck is it?
I want your listeners to look it up.
No, I'll be flashing it on the screen.
You flash it on the screen, because it has a
whole chapter on if we would just pay attention
to this cooperation within our own body of ourselves, we would have a different world.
And we're walking miracles.
The fact that we don't have to pay attention
to our breathing or our blood flow or our
lymph or all of this stuff, that's a miracle.
But I began seeing this concept that, wait a minute, what runs all of this?
What else can it be but divine, nothing else?
And I have to be really careful in my world,
because a lot of people, they think that's
religious, which means that then it's going to be discretionary, I mean, which religion
are you, right?
No, no, it's way beyond that.
It's way beyond that.
It's recognizing this world we live in is a miracle, and each one of us and each one
of that cellular connection, we're walking miracles.
And that's how we work with the TTouch and we work with animals is acknowledging
that potential, taking the animal beyond instinct.
This is why I don't use this concept of operant
conditioning, because I think that's limiting
their potential.
And you have worked with some animals, well,
let me, I know you've worked with some animals
that are considered dangerous, but I recall,
it's on YouTube, there's a woman who goes
to the island, I think it's off of Japan, where the Komodo dragons live.
These are man-eating reptiles, and she comes up and hugs them.
And I've often been just amazed, like, what
does she find within herself that allows her
to come and hug an animal that is known for eating humans?
Yeah, I don't know, because I wouldn't do it.
And one of the reasons I wouldn't do it is
that if I make a mistake and that animal reacts
instinctively and hurts me, it's going to be
punished, or it's going to get a bad reputation.
So I really recommend that people be very
discerning and respectful of how we are with
animals.
So I'm really careful not to threaten them.
And there is, oh my gosh, there is, I wish I
could remember her name, there is one beautiful
experience on YouTube of an animal communicator
working with a black panther in South Africa.
It's one of the most beautiful animal communications that I know of.
And this panther's name was Devil, and he was really aggressive and unfriendly and
afraid and withdrawn.
And she just went in and talked with him,
they changed his name, which I've been doing
for many, many years, changed the name.
And this animal, when she talked to him, he completely changed.
And that's something that I have found that,
you know, I've had, I bought a horse once
really cheap called Fighting Mad.
He was a junior jumper.
And they said, I got him so cheap because they said he bites and kicks and he doesn't
like people.
I took him home, put him on my own stable.
I didn't tell any of my people what his real
name was or that he had a problem, and I called
him Jumping Jack.
And from that day on, he was different.
Well, you know, now that you mention it, one
of the first dogs I ever had I named Fang.
And that dog bit my girlfriend Judy Rabinowitz at the time.
I shouldn't have named the dog Fang.
No, that's right.
And I don't understand why this is true.
And also, like, giving an animal a name that
has a personality rather than the name of
some mountain or something, I just think it's respectful.
It's really interesting.
You see, in the past, animals have been really important to our physical survival.
You know, dogs for herding, for watch, dogs for pulling, for all of this stuff.
Long before recorded history, we had these relationships.
We did.
But Jeffrey, today, I believe animals are just as important for our survival, but our
spiritual survival.
And this is what we see with people who have
dogs and cats and bunnies and little critters,
all the little creatures, mice.
Something happens when we dare to open our hearts to them.
And it's really a gift when we suddenly realize, wait a minute.
You know, people now, they refer to, they're
the mom and the dad of the animals, most of
the dogs.
You don't see it much with cats, but it's mostly with dogs, right?
Because that's how we feel, and that's really important.
And there was a book called Starseed Transmission by, I think, Ken Carey.
And on page 11, I remembered that he said,
before the fall of man in the, no, since the
fall of man in the Garden of Eden, when we lost
our ability to communicate with the animals,
we've been disconnected from our source.
And the animals give us that connection back to source.
Now, when I tried to find it in his book, I couldn't find the exact quote, but I quoted
that for years.
And I think acknowledging whether it's a bird
or it doesn't matter what this little being
can be.
It's the geckos on our walls in Hawaii.
I can feed them, and that connection takes
us out of ourselves acknowledging this other
being.
Let me ask you this question.
I think we have a certain affinity with other
mammals and with other vertebrates, such as
ourselves, but what about the invertebrates?
They seem so different.
Insects and snails.
Cell to cell.
Cell to cell.
It's really interesting when you start seeing,
when I see the beauty of divine spirit in
every being, it makes a change in my consciousness.
And I am sure that you must have by now read
about now the knowledge that trees have a
whole communication system.
Yes, I have.
You've got to interview that author.
I've ordered the book, and I haven't yet read
it because I'm deep in this other book right
now.
But it's really important for us to understand
these beautiful, it's not just animal communication.
It's our communication with the trees and
the butterflies and the bushes and the rocks.
It's as if a whole forest is a single organism.
Yes, and that's what's being shown.
It's a brilliant world we live in, and it's
interesting because living in Hawaii, we live
in the suburbs of Keaho, on the Big Island.
And I had never been dog-less before.
And so I said to my husband, Roland, I can't get along without a dog in my life.
